positive.review:
Grim Dawn is often spoken of as though it were merely a distant echo of Diablo, born in its shadow and destined never to escape it. Yet this is a misconception. Yes, its lineage is impossible to deny — the isometric perspective, the relentless combat, the endless hunt for loot, the dank caverns and infernal beasts — all these remind one of Blizzard’s legacy. But here the similarity ends. Grim Dawn is not a tale of a world fighting against damnation. It is a tale set long after damnation has already won. Humanity is not resisting the end — it is sifting through its ashes. What remains of the world is cracked, rusted, quiet. Here, magic is no divine gift, but a disease that clings to the flesh of the dying. The gods are silent. Salvation is no longer on offer. And it is this silence that gives the game its unmistakable presence.

The world of Grim Dawn does not tell its story with pompous cutscenes or heroic proclamations. It whispers it through scorched journals found in abandoned farms, through the final scribbles of dying soldiers, through broken machinery and crumbling village walls. The narrative is not handed down like scripture, but unearthed like bones. And upon these bones grows one of the most intricate role-playing systems the genre has seen. The dual-class mechanic, at first glance familiar, reveals itself to be a marvel of creative freedom: arcanist-soldiers, occultist-shamans, necromancer-demolitionists — combinations that should not make sense, and yet they do. Add to this the Devotion system — constellations of ancient powers drawn across a darkened sky, each gifting subtle strength — and building a character becomes less like ticking boxes, and more like practising alchemy: deliberate, risky, and strangely beautiful.

Combat in Grim Dawn does not dazzle the eye — it weighs upon the hand. Every swing, every explosion feels tangible, as though steel genuinely meets bone, and fire truly burns through oil and cloth. The music does not soar to angelic heights, as in Diablo II; rather, it seeps into the world like mist over moorland — quiet, mournful, ever-present. It belongs not to heroes, but to survivors. It is not a hymn of hope, but the low hum of a forge still burning in a ruined town because to stop would mean admitting defeat. And in this weariness lies a peculiar comfort.

One cannot, in fairness, compare Grim Dawn to Diablo IV in terms of production spectacle. Crate Entertainment does not possess Blizzard’s coffers, nor its orchestras, actors, or cinematic bombast. But what they do possess is rarer: craftsmanship, resolve, and a kind of honest reverence for the genre. Grim Dawn does not flatter the player, nor beg for applause — it simply exists, solid and unpretentious, like an old stone bridge built to endure storms rather than impress passers-by. It expects you to learn, to fail, to rise, and try again — and in return, it offers a world that respects your time and intelligence.

Thus, Grim Dawn is not a “Diablo clone,” but rather a parallel branch of ARPG evolution. If Diablo is myth — glorious, biblical — then Grim Dawn is chronicle. If Diablo sings of saving the world, Grim Dawn quietly asks what one does when the world is already lost. And in that simple, solemn question lies its strength. It stands, firmly and humbly, somewhere between Diablo II and Diablo III — not to surpass them, but to walk its own road, through fog, mud and broken steel.

Grim Dawn is a Dark-Fantasy ARPG originally crafted in 2016 by a studio of less than 10 developers. Having played a decent amount of ARPGs before like Path of Exile, Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing, Torchlight or Diablo 4, i will say that Grim Dawn gave me the most amount of enjoyment for the time invested. I got the base game on heavy discount but later bought all expansions full price to experience the game to it's full extend.

[b][u]Classes:[/u][/b]
There is no fancy character creator, you basically directly jump into action and upon first leveling up, you will have to chose one out of 6 (9 with Expansions) classes. When reaching level 10 you decide which secondary class you want to play which allows for up to 45 different class combinations. The decision is final for that character so if you want to test out the other possibilities you will have to create a new character.

[b][u]Build/Respec:[/u][/b]
Classes are the only aspect of the game that you will lock in completely. Everything else can be changed however you see fit. The respec-cost is minimal at first but will increase with the amount of times you made use of the system (but it's capped so it's impossible to brick your character at some point).

[b][u]Loot/Gear/Crafting:[/u][/b]
Of all the ARPGs i played i like the Loot and Crafting system in Grim Dawn the best. You get plenty of Loot on your adventures and the dynamic level scaling allows you to revisit starting areas on higher difficulties and still find upgrades. Minibosses and most elites each have items that are guaranteed to drop (so called "Monster Infrequents") which tremendously help getting the build of your choice rolling before Endgame. Later you will find Recipies for Legendary Gear aswell as full legendary Item drops to keep the Gearprogression going. For Set-items, you have the possiblity to craft multiple helmets for example and transmute them into the missing Setpieces so once you find the recipe, you can craft the whole set. In Addition you will find Components to further tailor your gear to your needs. Same goes for Augments (which are sold by merchants) that mostly cover your defensive resistances. There is no targetfarming for Legendaries, everything can drop everywhere so the game does a great job not locking you into boring grinding of the same activity (but it can be quite frustrating sometimes if that one piece you're missing for your build doesn't drop). Grim Dawn also has a very nice Lootfilter directly integrated.

[b][u]Story/World:[/u][/b]
Lets face it, noone plays ARPGs for the story, but it does it's job well enough to keep you somewhat invested. The interesting part is Grim Dawns faction system where you collect favors and reputation doing quests. The higher your reputation, the more items will be unlocked for the faction merchant. Same goes the other way around tho, you lose reputation for rivaling factions and upon maxing it out, they will send special bosses (nemesis) that are tough to take down but drop good loot. Each difficulty is it's seperate campaign, so you can side with one faction on normal difficulty while siding with the other faction on Elite or Ultimate Difficulty. Quests are in general straightforward (kill x of these, collect x of that) but there are some nice hidden quests aswell as hidden areas. Unfortunately there's one big secret Quests that you cant do if you side with the wrong faction, both secret quests from the storyexpansions can be done regardless of your decisions made in the game.

[b][u]Endgame:[/u][/b]
Beside gearprogression, there are a few pinnacle bosses that pose a real threat. In addition to that, the Crucible DLC added a Horde mode with minor tower defense mechanics. The Forgotten Gods Expansion added the Shattered Realm, an Endless Dungeon on a timer that increases in difficulty the deeper you go. I beat Crucible and it was a nice way to farm legendaries. For the Shattered Realm on the other hand you need a very good build with even better gear to advance to the levels with worthy loot. My build hit a wall around Ultimate lvl35 and it just wasn't enjoyable grinding Nemesis bosses with 10m+ hp for minutes. I like the fact that if you just want to experience everything the game has to offer, you dont need a perfect build. But if you really want to, you can grind forever to minmax everything. The Endgame emphasis definitly lies in playing new characters and testing new builds

[b][u]Difficulty/Complexity:[/u][/b]
I personally would put Grim Dawn between Diablo 4 (super casual) and Path of Exile (super nerdy/complex). Like mentioned above you can experience everything with a suboptimal build. But the game has enough depth in both skill- and talent tree to keep you engaged for at least 100 hours. I would still recommend using a Build Guide (Youtube/Grimtools) if new to the game so you get a better grasp what items to look out for.

[b][u]Some personal annoyances:[/u][/b]
- The biggest gripe i had with the game was always having to wait a moment for the loot to drop before automatically picking it up (components eg.), wish there was an option to remove or reduce the delay.
- The Basegame Secret Quest on Ultimate Difficulty was locked for my character because i sided with the Death Vigils Faction (for the Achievement) instead of the Kymons Chosen. So i would have had to create and grind another char to Endgame to experience it. Do yourself a favor and side with Kymons Chosen on Ultimate
- Enable VSync to cap the FPS, my GPU was flying 500+ fps for some reason before that ^^'
- Disable Keybind for Weaponswap (in the heat of battle i sometimes accidentaly pressed it since it was next to my HP potion)
- Disable Keybind for Camera Rotation (was next to the Map hotkey which i had opened half the time since compass was too small)
- Mutually exclusive achievement (finishing Questline on Ultimate for both Deaths Vigil and Kymons chosen requires me to play another char to endgame)
- Barrowholm Faction Trader is only unlocked if you sided with them on that difficulty (i have to switch difficulty every time i wanna buy something even tho i'm (now again) friendly with that faction on ultimate)
- Siding against Barrowholm locks you out of a pinnacle boss for that difficulty (i would only side against them on Elite for the achievement so you keep access to that boss on Normal and Ultimate)
- Generally my tip for Ultimate Difficulty: Side with Kymons Chosen (for secret quest), with Barrowholm (for Faction Merchant and Pinnacle Boss) and Outcast (for faction merchant) so you dont have to switch difficulties. In that regard, i would side with deaths Vigil faction on Normal/Elite difficulty and stock up on some of their augments before starting ultimate

I can honestly say Grim Dawn is one of the most rewarding ARPGs I’ve ever played. The atmosphere is dark and immersive, the combat is crunchy and satisfying, and the sheer amount of build variety kept me experimenting long after finishing the main story. The dual-class system is genius—it constantly tempts you to try “just one more” character.

What really sets Grim Dawn apart is how much it respects your time. Every dungeon crawl, faction choice, and loot drop feels meaningful. The expansions and endgame content add even more depth, making the world of Cairn feel endless.

After countless hours, I managed to unlock every single achievement—and that journey was incredible. From surviving hardcore mode to tackling the toughest bosses, each milestone felt like a badge of honor. It wasn’t just about grinding; it was about mastering the game’s systems and truly conquering its challenges.

If you’re into ARPGs and want something that combines old-school grit with modern polish, Grim Dawn is a must-play. And if you’re the type who loves chasing achievements, trust me—it’s worth going all the way.

The other big thing I appreciate is that for almost every idea you could have there's at least some support. Some conversion combos are less supported than others, but in general if you decide you want your giant laser to be effectively necrotic? There's support for that. Want your Beefy swordsman to be unfettered by the concept of physical damage because it's all elemental now? There's ample support for that.

The one warning I'd give is that there will be times where you're not entirely sure what killed you, but it always boils down to "work on your resistances" because the game is actually pretty fair with the number of "circuit breaker" skills you can get your hands on to shave off or prevent damage...unless your resists are in the dumps and you get one shot.

Grim Dawn is a heavily atmospheric post-apocalyptic isometric rpg where you plow through hordes of enemies in the name of being a complete fucking badass. To simplify it, this game is like Diablo, but better! The videos on the store page don't do it justice, there's something truly special about running through the countryside slaughtering every unholy abomination that stands in your way. Furthermore, there's a lot of diversity in what your playstyle can be, you can lean really hard into a specific archetype or cherry pick skills here and there from every archetype. My personal favorite is the Demolitionist because it lets me run around with a supercharged shotgun, and retaliate with an explosion when I get touched on something like a 4 second cooldown. That's just enough time for me to run up on a group, kill half of them with the shotgun, and then wipe the rest out with the explosion when one of them inevitably attacks. I know that many a year ago, when I tried the game for the first time, I had played a Necromancer who ran around clubbing things to death. It wasn't very effective, but it was fun.

And honestly, I think thats why I like this game so much. It has the atmosphere and storytelling that you'd look for in this type of grim (ha) story, but at the end of the day you could just forego caring about the story and just use it as a vehicle for your own personalized killing spree.

After more than 750 hours of playing this game, I can confidently say it is the closest any ARPG has come to capturing the feel of the original Diablo II (outside of Diablo II: Resurrected). The depth, atmosphere, and gameplay systems put it in a league of its own.

Character & Class Customization

The customization options are extraordinary. The ability to mix and match different classes—or "masteries"—allows you to tailor your character exactly how you want to play. Much like Titan Quest, hybrid builds are not only possible but encouraged. Across all my hours, I don't believe I’ve come across a build that can’t complete the main campaign. While some setups clearly excel in endgame content, every build is at least capable of clearing through the full game.

Attributes & Devotion System

The attribute system is simple, intuitive, and easy to understand—very standard but well executed.

The devotion system, however, is a standout feature. It functions almost like a secondary talent tree that adds tremendous depth and power to your build. With the right planning, devotion choices can completely transform your gameplay and open up some incredibly powerful combinations. I highly recommend using GrimTools to locate all the devotion shrines and optimize your setup.

Gameplay & Atmosphere

The gameplay experience is exceptionally engaging. Combat feels impactful, animations are smooth, and the pacing strikes a perfect balance between tactical positioning and relentless action. The dark, gritty environments capture the essence of classic ARPGs and maintain a strong thematic tone throughout the campaign and endgame.

Enemy encounters are well varied, boss fights often require awareness and preparation, and the overall difficulty curve feels rewarding rather than punishing. Controls are responsive, build synergies feel meaningful, and progression always gives you something new to chase—whether it's new skills, gear upgrades, or deeper mechanics to refine.

Loot & Progression

The loot system is outstanding. Item drops feel impactful and meaningful, rarities are well balanced, and the game consistently rewards experimentation. Legendary and set items often promote specific build ideas, encouraging creativity rather than forcing meta choices. There's a satisfying variety of affixes, crafting options, and item modifications, all of which support long-term build development.

Farming feels purposeful rather than tedious, and the layering of different item types—rare drops, crafted gear, components, and augmentations—creates a deep but approachable progression loop. Every upgrade feels earned, and there’s genuine excitement in finding gear that unlocks a new level of potential for your build.

Overall, this game delivers an exceptional ARPG experience that honors its roots while providing immense build freedom and rewarding progression. For fans of classic Diablo II-style gameplay, it is as close as it gets without being the real thing.
